content.description: Crux is the top 3' arm crack.  This can be skipped though and the crack used to build the trad anchor.
content.protection: All types: small nuts to large cams.  Can get away with nothing larger than a #3 camalot.
content.location: Left of Amazon Woman and South Africa.  Follow the line of least resistance by the coast of South America, but stay left or else you'll end up on South Africa.  Ends either at the arm chimney or on top of it.  I recommend to belay the second from here and then rap/climb to Amazon Woman anchors.  Its really an easy 5th class traverse, but you want to be roped up!

content.description: Crux is down low traversing out and up into a finger crack.  About 20' from the start.
content.protection: Couple large pieces are nice (#3 camalot or larger).  Few small to protect the crux move out the lieback and into the finger crack.
content.location: Follow the coast of South America all the way up.  Can drouble rap (2 ropes) from Amazon Woman anchors (barely).  Tie a knot in the loose end and make sure the not by the chains is a good 5-10' from the chains, otherwise you'll never be able to pull the ropes due to the knot friction going over the top of the continent.

content.description: A contrived variation to L.A. Woman.  Just needs the right leader.
content.location: Star on L.A. start traverse right below the Bondage traverse.  Climb the face right of the water streak.

climbs.name: L.A. Woman
climbs.fa: Sam Audrain, Jon Frank, Duane Raleigh, Jimmy Ratzlaff, 1981

content.description: The pro is nill.  Truly an R (runout) route.  stout 5.10 face climbing between bolts and 5.11 sections.  It is not advised to fall on this route.  Can be toproped off Amazon Woman anchors.  Lead from ground up on FA.
content.location: Breaks off from Amazon Woman, to the right and follows the bolts

content.description: Climb the steep face to clip the only bolt finish moves lead to a ledge.  Short
content.location: Left of the start for South Pacific.

content.description: Climb the first 3 bolts of L.A. and traverse right to the water streak.  Crux is after the last bolt on an overhang.

Another must do at Quartz.  Crux is at 1st bolt moving right onto the main face, then climb small edges, dishes and mantles up to the last bolt.  Crux is mantleing onto the polished dishes above the bulge.
content.location: At the base of the South America formation.  Spot the first bolt and climb trending left, connecting bolts.

content.description: About 3/4 of the way down the primary formation seen from the parking lot.  The usual lines typical of Quartz.
